title: Historic Scottish Castle With Dungeons Selling for £1.23 Million
text:
A historic Scottish castle that boasts architectural relics spanning 500 years is selling for £1.23 million (US$1.49 million).



The earliest section of Craig Castle, a turreted stone manor nestled in the rolling foothills of the Grampian mountains, dates to the 1500s, according to Historic Scotland, a database of significant sites. Centuries of extensions have culminated in a maze-like family home with a guard’s room, dungeon cells, a baronial hall and a now-boarded escape tunnel.



The estate, located in the village of Rhynie, about an hour west of Aberdeen, hit the market on Thursday and spans 1,561 acres—four and a half times the size of London’s Hyde Park.



An ornate arched gateway constructed in the first half of the 18th century guards the castle entrance and bears the initials of members of the Gordon family, who built much of the estate and were its stewards for over 300 years.



There are even remnants of an original doorbell at the entryway, the sound of which would have rung out “giving off the impression of momentous occasion,” according to the listing agents, Strutt & Parker.



The oldest portion of the castle features dramatic barrel-vaulted ceilings and centuries of heraldry, including family coats of arms from various generations of Gordons. It also contains most of the home's quirkiest architectural elements, including a historic guard’s room on the ground floor, complete with an adjacent dungeon cell. There’s also a co-called “priest hole”—a hiding place for clergy during a time when Catholics were persecuted—and what is believed to be a now-blocked escape tunnel, according the listing agents.



A spiral staircase from the ground floor leads to an impressive baronial hall that originally served as a chapel and up to the third and fourth floors, which contain two of the castle’s nine bedrooms.



The Gordons added a substantial three-story wing overlooking the estate's walled garden in the 17th century. Today, it includes a library and another dizzying spiral staircase that ascends to four en-suite bedrooms. The most recent addition to the castle, in the early 1900s, created additional bedrooms and a new kitchen, according to the listing agents.

By the 1950s, the castle served as the home of Col. Alexander Barlas and Lady Gertrude Craik, and has remained in family hands for generations, according to the listing agents. The owners could not be reached for comment.

The castle isn’t the only historical site on the property. There’s also a B-listed sundial dating back nearly 200 years and a stone garden wall built in the 18th century, according to Historic Scotland.
